#  The best wireless headphones

  *   *   *   * 

Save

Save

![best wireless headphones review](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/best-
wireless-headphones-review-
summary_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=450)

  * [Jack Rear](/authors/jack-rear/)

3 March 2020 • 12:15pm

Follow

### Follow the author of this article

  * [ Jack Rear ](/authors/jack-rear/)

### Follow the topics within this article

  * [ Gadgets ](/gadgets-products/)
  * [ Headphones ](/headphones/)
  * [ Beats ](/beats-by-dre/)

In the search for the best wireless headphones, you quickly encounter three
levels of 'purity'.

First, there are ‘true wireless’ headphones, which are basically two ear plugs
that have no wires whatsoever. The most recognisable example are the Apple
AirPods – small white buds that slot into your ear and leave little trace on
your silhouette. They're as pure as can be.

Then there are headphones that share a wire, running around the back of your
neck or over your head, that links right ear to left. These will connect
wirelessly to your smartphone or speaker, normally over Bluetooth. They're
often liked by sporty types, because the wire keeps them held together.

And finally there are 'hybrid' headphones, which can connect over Bluetooth,
but also come with a standard headphone cable. These are almost always over-
ear headphones, and they make up a large proportion of the market.

All three types are technically wireless headphones, and you’ll find examples
of all three varieties in this guide. They come with their own pros and cons –
for example, true wireless headphones are almost faff-free but need frequent
charging; while hybrid headphones offer you the most dexterity – so it’s
really a case of you deciding which design meets your needs.

There’s basically no real difference between the sound quality, so it’s really
just about which design you find most comfortable and which suits your
aesthetic.

While I had no real problems with the wireless qualities of the headphones I
reviewed, I’m prepared to admit that I’m not the most musically-inclined
person, so I sought the advice of musician and West End sound technician [Karl
Toth](https://www.karltoth.co.uk/), who tested each pair of headphones and
talked me through their individual audio merits and demerits.

Here’s what we found when looking for the best wireless headphones on the
market, starting with our absolute favourite…

### **1\. Creative Super X-Fi Air**

**Why we like them:** They make your music sound like you’re in the room with
the band

[£149.99, Creative](https://uk.creative.com/p/super-x-fi/creative-sxfi-air)

![Creative Super X-Fi Air best wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Creative-Super-X-Fi-Air_Best-
wireless-
headphones_recommended_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=480)

While you may not have heard of Creative Technology, you will almost have
certainly used one of their products. The Singapore-based company are arguably
one of the most influential tech companies in the world today. Their original
sound card is the reason we have computer speakers to this day.

The Super X-Fi Air headphones were the toast of this year’s Consumer
Electronics Show, where critics called them “mind-blowing” and described using
them as an “eargasm”. Quite the reputation to live up to.

Initially, both Toth and I were decidedly unimpressed. The padding on the cups
feels cheap, and the customisable light-up rings on the cups feels rather like
a distracting gimmick than a luxury feature. More alarmingly, the sound was
hit-and-miss: Toth described the high end of the sound spectrum being “pushed
to the limits of still being listenable”.

And then we pushed a button and the world moved beneath our feet. You see,
we'd been using the Super X-Fi Air wrongly. There's an accompanying app that
has a function that moulds the sound to your ears. How? You use your phone or
tablet to take a picture of each of your ears, then your head, and Creative’s
algorithm uses the shapes of each to test your hearing and adapt the
headphones to you. (I’m told this is the most efficient way of doing so,
without spending a tonne of time and money to get your ears tested in a
professional environment.)

Immediately the whole listening experience changed, says Toth. “It feels like
it went from listening to someone in the next room to the wall coming down.
They’re incredible, they make me feel giddy like a child.”

The same goes if you take a phone call on them. It honestly makes the person
on the other end of the line sound like they are speaking to you in the same
room. The sound fidelity is so phenomenally good, I stopped caring about that
cheap padding completely.

There’s a number of other nice features too like touch controls on the cups,
so you can tap to play and pause your music, or swipe to adjust the volume or
skip through tracks. And you can insert a microSD card to be able to listen to
music without having to connect to your phone via Bluetooth.

Finally, I have to commend the equitability of Creative. For those who’d like
the benefits of hyper-personalised music but already have a pair of
headphones, it might be worth seeking out the [Super X-Fi
Amp](https://uk.creative.com/p/super-x-fi/creative-sxfi-amp) which plugs into
your current headphones to adjust the sound input for your ears, giving a
similar experience to Creative’s own product. Simply do the hearing test,
select your own headphones from a drop down menu (everything from Beats to
those cheap headphones that come with iPhones are featured) and you’ll get
that Super X-Fi experience on your current favourite pair.

_[Buy now](https://uk.creative.com/p/super-x-fi/creative-sxfi-air)_

### **2\. Beats Solo3 Wireless**

**Why we like them:** They’re perfectly tuned for modern music

[£199, Currys PC
World](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=1599&awinaffid=73846&clickref=AsPLCJcLzMnT&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.currys.co.uk%2Fgbuk%2Faudio-
and-headphones%2Fheadphones%2Fheadphones%2Fbeats-solo-3-wireless-bluetooth-
headphones-black-10152178-pdt.html)

![Beats Solo3 Wireless best
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Beats-Solo3-Wireless_best-
headphones_secondary_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=480)

While the company is one of the most recognisable names in headphones around
the world, Beats are still likely to get a few eye-rolls among a professional
crowd. “They’re seen as being a bit basic, a bit ‘pretend-pro’," says Toth.
"You wear Beats to seem like you’re an audiophile when you don’t really know
what you’re doing."

Even so, there’s no denying that Beats have found a loyal audience and have
become almost a status symbol for the iPhone generation. And to be fair, says
Toth, there’s a good reason for that. “These are tuned for modern pop music,
they’re really good at that. Everything is adjusted just the right amount to
make it sound excellent. The high stuff is really shimmery and there’s a nice
bass on the lower end. You can just chuck these on and you know you’re going
to get a good experience every time.”

The design of the Solo3 headphones plays into that millennial luxury feel too.
They’re bulky but not too bulky, making just enough of a statement while also
feeling comfortable and modest enough to wear casually. The leather pads feel
good and don’t easily slip off (no matter how much head-banging you do), and
the range of colours is always a nice option.

One particularly impressive feature is the battery. These babies will last 40
hours off a full charge, but even plugging them for five minutes gave me three
hours and seven minutes playtime, making them ideal for forgetful types who
never remember to charge their gadgets before a long trip.

One minor disappointment is that the Solo3 headphones employ a physical button
to control them. One tap for play/pause, two to skip forwards, three to skip
backwards, and a tap at the top or bottom raises or lowers the volume. It’s a
fairly self-explanatory system, but it's a bit fiddly to use and it feels
slightly too easy to mess up. You end up pressing the volume button when you
mean to pause, or triple tap the button too fast and end up pausing the music
rather than skipping back to the last track.

Either way, if you’re looking for a pair of headphones that you can quickly
throw on and enjoy, look no further.

_[Buy
now](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=1599&awinaffid=73846&clickref=AsPLCJcLzMnT&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.currys.co.uk%2Fgbuk%2Faudio-
and-headphones%2Fheadphones%2Fheadphones%2Fbeats-solo-3-wireless-bluetooth-
headphones-black-10152178-pdt.html)_

### **3\. Beyer Dynamic Amiron Wireless**

**Why we like them:** The gold standard for true audiophiles

[£555.55, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/beyerdynamic-Amiron-Wireless-High-
End-Headphone-Black-
Silver/dp/B079P4348N?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Beyer Dynamic Amiron Wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Beyer-Dynamic-Amiron-
Wireless_wireless-
headphones_secondary_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=480)

“Beyer Dynamic are considered the industry standard,” explains Toth as he
takes these out of the box.

Right from the off, there’s a noticeably premium feel to these (matching that
eye-watering price). Each one comes with a unique, individual serial number
which is… well, it’s basically meaningless for most of us, but it does help
sell the whole “premium” thing. The cups are made of metal with a luxurious
and hyper-comfortable suede padding. They clap together nicely to feel tight
enough on your head to stay in place no matter what.

These are big, bulky headphones that are designed for studio use, not
necessarily meant to be worn on the train to and from work. Still, that
doesn’t mean that they’re not absolutely pitch perfect at what they do.

The Amiron Wireless headphones are a far cry from Beats in terms of the sound
they emit. “They’re subdued and more professional, the sound quality is super
clear and defined," says Toth. "They’re ideal for recording, this is what you
want if you’re referencing studio mixes.”

Basically, everything is so clear and unmodified that if you need to compare
minute differences between two tracks, these are the ones you need. But
they’re mind-blowingly good at what they do. There’s an incredible thrill in
hearing music sound this precise; you can imagine the original artist sitting
in the room, carefully composing every sound, every note, so they were all
just perfect for you.

Having said that, Toth does describe the Amiron Wireless headphones as being
“a cake without a cherry”. He says they’re not ideal for the average listener,
because they don’t really soup up anything, leaving them sounding a bit flat
compared to the likes of Beats or Super X-Fi.

Even so, if you’re a true audiophile who wants to listen to music just as it
was originally recorded, or a musician who needs to hear with perfect clarity,
these are simply the best in the field.

_[B uy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/beyerdynamic-Amiron-Wireless-High-End-
Headphone-Black-
Silver/dp/B079P4348N?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **4\. Master & Dynamic MW07**

**Why we like them:** They’re a very premium take on true wireless headphones

[£239.99, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Master-Dynamic-Bluetooth-Earphones-
Headphones-Grey-
Terrazzo/dp/B07H8RZN47?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Master & Dynamic MW07 best true wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Master-Dynamic-MW07_best-true-
wireless-
headphones_secondary_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=480)

Our first set of ‘true wireless’ headphones on this list and they’re a doozy.
Master & Dynamic are another big name in the world of headphones and, true to
form, they’ve crafted a very impressive product here.

Once again, we’re looking at a product designed to be ‘premium’. The
headphones themselves look unique with a tile-like exterior that has an
interesting marble pattern visible in your ears. Master & Dynamic also win
points for the charging case, which is made of polished steel rather than the
plastic of some other options. It looks incredible if you can accept that it
will definitely end up covered in fingerprints.

Once again, each set was hand-made and comes with a distinct serial number.

It’d be fair to say the headphones aren’t exactly the most comfortable things
to begin with, although I did find that I got used to them pretty quickly. On
the plus side, they stay in your ears nicely; even after a lot of shaking and
jumping around, I couldn’t dislodge them. They come with multiple different
kinds of ear-tips, so you can personalise the fit.

As for the sound quality, they’re excellent. Everything is intelligently
levelled in a way that seems particularly sensitive to the needs of modern
music, though that’s not to say older stuff doesn’t sound great as well. You
can hear every instrument distinctly, which is an important test of quality,
according to Toth.

One thing that did surprise me was just how loud the MW07 units can go. You
might think they’d hold back on the volume, given that they’re so small, but
that’s not the case at all.

Battery life is a slight disappointment. You only get about three and a half
hours from the headphones. The case can charge them a further three times too,
so you could theoretically get 14 hours of battery life altogether, but that’s
still considerably less than other true wireless headphones.

Still, there’s no denying the aesthetic of these little earbuds and their
ability to give a good musical performance.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Master-Dynamic-Bluetooth-Earphones-
Headphones-Grey-
Terrazzo/dp/B07H8RZN47?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **5\. Status Audio BT One**

**What we like about them:** The price

[£99, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Status-Audio-Wireless-Headphones-
Jetblack/dp/B07T27FQ5H/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)

![Status Audio BT One best wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2020/02/20/Status-Audio-BT-One_best-
wireless-
headphones_secondary_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.png?imwidth=480)

When you get them out of the box, you probably won’t think much of the BT One.
As headphones go, this one is light, plasticky, and feels cheap. There are no
frills here: no voice controls, no touch controls, no luxurious metal bits.

However, when the headphones go onto your head and you fire up the tunes, it
soon becomes clear that Status have really poured all their energy into making
sure the speakers are up to snuff. I’ve read comments from fellow critics
which claimed that the sound quality was up there with speakers for twice the
price and I can't disagree. The sound is rich and full, you can hear every
thump of the base, while the highs are bright and crisp. There is not a hint
of fuzziness or warble in any song I listened to. I am deeply impressed.

In the Beats era where a pair of headphones is as much a fashion accessory as
a means of listening to music, I’m not sure whether the BT One will find its
audience, but if it doesn’t, it won’t be for want of sound quality.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Status-Audio-Wireless-Headphones-
Jetblack/dp/B07T27FQ5H/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)_

### **6\. Jabra Elite 65T**

[£149.99, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Jabra-Wireless-Bluetooth-Charging-
One-touch-Titanium-
Black/dp/B078GMZ9PQ/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Jabra Elite 65T best wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Jabra-
Elite-65T_trans_NvBQzQNjv4Bqs6KvPvMH4OL3HvtIfdYOwlVse9JsN00kzbUr3IXHaGo.png?imwidth=480)

If I had to describe Jabra’s biggest mistake with these headphones, I would
put my finger on the word “Elite”. Between that name and the description on
the box, it’s hard to escape the idea that the brand was aiming to create a
high-end, premium product. But these earbuds feel a bit too plasticky and
cheap to be a good fit for that market.

However, if you can get past the misnomer, Jabra have actually crafted a
really very solid headphone here. The sound quality is top notch, says Toth,
able to hit some of the bassiest levels on the low end while maintaining the
sharpness on higher end stuff.

In addition, the battery life is seriously impressive – five hours off a
single charge, and then a further 15 in the charging case. That’d be fairly
decent for a pair of over-ear headphones, let alone some tiny true wireless
earbuds.

There’s also some really good noise-cancelling technology which works a treat,
as well as audio-transparency that you can turn off/on, allowing you to hear
the rest of the world while your music is playing; ideal for those who do a
lot of running on roads.

One of my personal favourite features was the compatibility with my phone’s
voice assistant, with a press of the button. The headphones simply listen out
for you to say “Hey Siri” or “OK Google” and respond in kind; it’s a handy
feature which avoids you needing to press any buttons.

That being said, Jabra’s big mistake here was the physical buttons used to
control volume and play/pause and skip through tracks. On an over-ear
headphone like the Beats Solo3, the force of the button press is spread across
your ear, whereas on an ear-bud, it just feels like you’re jamming it into
your ear canal.

However, given that you can control your music by simply taking your phone or
MP3 player out of your pocket, that isn’t necessarily a dealbreaker.

If you want some top quality true wireless headphones at a reasonable price
point, these are a great option.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Jabra-Wireless-Bluetooth-Charging-One-
touch-Titanium-
Black/dp/B078GMZ9PQ/ref=sr_1_1_sspa?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **7\. Echo Buds**

[£119.99, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/amazon-echo-buds-wireless-earbuds-
with-immersive-sound-active-noise-reduction-and-
alexa/dp/B07FWGBDN6/ref=sr_1_1?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)

![Echo Buds best true wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2020/02/20/Echo-Buds-best-true-wireless-
headphones_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqNJjoeBT78QIaYdkJdEY4CnGTJFJS74MYhNY6w3GNbO8.jpg?imwidth=480)

Ever since Alexa took over our homes with the Amazon Echo, it has only been a
matter of time until we’d be able to take the smart assistant with us and use
it on the road. Sure, there’s been an app for a long time, but seeing as
almost every phone has either Siri or Google Assistant baked in, there’s
really been no good reason to use it on the fly. Until now.

The Echo Buds are a pair of true-wireless headphones which are defined by the
fact they have three microphones in each bud, designed specifically to listen
out for voice commands to Alexa.

It's something that has been tried before, but never successfully. Whenever
I’ve tested smart assistant enabled headphones, they’ve been poor at picking
up commands. Generally I’d end up having to get my phone out of my pocket
anyway. But Amazon and Bose, who collaborated on the Echo Buds, have succeeded
here; the headphones picked up my commands every time with no fuss. Even in
crowded, noisy, or windy conditions, they had no trouble hearing me.

If you’re less interested in using Alexa, the Echo Buds are a bit of a mixed
bag. The speaker quality is certainly impressive, and the basic touch commands
on the headphones work well, but the noise-cancellation just isn’t up to
scratch. I could hear a constant fuzzy humming. Very distracting.

If you’re an Alexa-aficionado, look no further, the Echo Buds work well and
they’re not too expensive compared to comparable products. If you’re less
bothered about the smart assistant then you can do better.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/amazon-echo-buds-wireless-earbuds-with-
immersive-sound-active-noise-reduction-and-
alexa/dp/B07FWGBDN6/ref=sr_1_1?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)_

### **8\. Sennheiser Momentum True Wireless**

[£279, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Sennheiser-MOMENTUM-True-Wireless-
Transparent-Black-
Silver/dp/B07HRHM8F3/ref=asc_df_B07HRHM8F3/?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Sennheiser Momentum True Wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Sennheiser-Momentum-True-
Wireless_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqNJjoeBT78QIaYdkJdEY4CnGTJFJS74MYhNY6w3GNbO8.jpg?imwidth=480)

In terms of speaker quality, Toth was very impressed with the Momentum True
Wireless headphones. “They’re a fun headphone, you’ve got a loads of levels, a
lot of low stuff. These are the kind of headphones that are easy to stick on
and enjoy, like Beats.”

There are other ways these feel nice too. The charging case comes with a
charming fabric skin. It’s not the shiny silver box of the Master & Dynamic
MW07, but for my money, I thought it looked pretty sharp, and hey, at least
you won’t spend your life scrubbing fingersprints off this one.

You can control the headphones by simply tapping on the outside. There’s no
button pressing involved here, so you don’t need to worry about jamming them
down your ear canal.

Battery life is reasonable too. You get around four hours of play time off a
full charge, then the charging case can give you another eight hours if you
don’t mind waiting.

My only real disappointment was with the fit. I was able to dislodge these
from my head quite easily when I was moving around, so I probably wouldn’t
recommend exercising with them in. However, if you’re content to sit at your
desk and listen to music, you could do worse.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Sennheiser-MOMENTUM-True-Wireless-
Transparent-Black-
Silver/dp/B07HRHM8F3/ref=asc_df_B07HRHM8F3/?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **9\. BeatsX**

[£109, John
Lewis](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=1203&awinaffid=73846&clickref=customid&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.johnlewis.com%2Fbeats-
wireless-bluetooth-in-ear-headphones-with-mic-remote%2Fp3813457)

![BeatsX best wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/BeatsX_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqNJjoeBT78QIaYdkJdEY4CnGTJFJS74MYhNY6w3GNbO8.jpg?imwidth=480)

Another set of Beats headphones, and this one abandons the classic over-ear
look that has come to define the brand in favour of a cord which goes around
the back of the neck instead, ensuring that even if the buds themselves fall
from your ears, they’re still attached to your person and not skittering down
beneath the wheels of an oncoming train.

The look is pretty sleek and the back of the headphones are magnetic so you
can fasten them around you when not in use. So far, so handy.

Unfortunately the cable is weighted a bit oddly, causing it to bounce around a
lot when you move. The controls are located on a toggle on the cable, and I
found that reaching up to play with them pulled the closest headphone out of
my ear about half the time.

That being said, when you’re not messing with the buttons, BeatsX do fit
fantastically well and don’t drop out of your ears easily.

As for the music quality, it’s a little odd. The high stuff is really shimmery
and sharp, but the middle is pretty flat. The contrast between the two is
quite strange. Neither would be a negative on its own, but combined they work
to make music feel very on-edge. It’s not the worst thing in the world but
Toth says he wouldn’t want to listen to them for too long. You’ll only get
eight hours before they’ll need a recharge, so that may not be too much of a
problem.

_[Buy
now](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=1203&awinaffid=73846&clickref=customid&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.johnlewis.com%2Fbeats-
wireless-bluetooth-in-ear-headphones-with-mic-remote%2Fp3813457)_

### **10\. Urbanista Seattle**

[£89, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Urbanista-Seattle-Wireless-Headphone-
Rose-Gold/dp/B01LZ6TZ85?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Urbanista Seattle wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Urbanista-
Seattle_trans_NvBQzQNjv4Bq0yK5MBq0qjXDnFbbkJu7CPbc9bSguvzUbMhnQpDTdKg.png?imwidth=480)

My review unit came in a delightful rose gold, and, for my money, they looked
by far the best of any of the headphones on this list. They also felt
comfortable and clamp securely to your head so they don’t fall off too easily.

The sound quality is fairly clear, though Toth notes that they sound a little
flat. “They need an EQ boost, you want more low-end stuff, and it feels like
some clarity is missing here. They’re also a bit quiet compared to others
we’ve tested, even at full volume.”

_[B uy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Urbanista-Seattle-Wireless-Headphone-
Rose-Gold/dp/B01LZ6TZ85?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **11\. Mixx Audio JX1**

[£19.99, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/JX1-Bluetooth-Wireless-Stereo-
Headphones/dp/B0786KB5NM?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)

![Mixx Audio JX1 wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Mixx-Audio-
JX1_trans_NvBQzQNjv4Bq1AT3Q7Sc9uaffdHBes0nLoAUi_eAXJmjTzXoJ-
uDM54.jpg?imwidth=480)

Compare the price of these to the price of the top picks, and you should get a
good idea of what to expect. “There’s nothing on the low end, everything is a
bit underwhelming, a bit boring,” says Toth. “They’re not that bad, just
nothing to write home about – they do the job fine.”

The construction isn’t that great either. That being said, they are
surprisingly comfortable to wear, and the light-weight plastic means you can
wear them for ages without ever feeling uncomfortable.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/JX1-Bluetooth-Wireless-Stereo-
Headphones/dp/B0786KB5NM?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=AsPLCJcLzMnT-21)_

### **12\. Urbanista Tokyo**

[£69.99, Clas
Ohlsen](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6625&awinaffid=73846&clickref=customid&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.clasohlson.com%2Fuk%2FUrbanista-
Tokyo-Wireless-Earphones%2F38-8704-1)

![Urbanista Tokyo best true wireless
headphones](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Urbanista-
Tokyo_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqqVzuuqpFlyLIwiB6NTmJwfSVWeZ_vEN7c6bHu2jJnT8.jpg?imwidth=480)

All in all, Urbanista have made a pretty good set of headphones with their
Tokyo true wireless earbuds. They’re very loud, and sound reasonably good
given the relatively low price point.

Battery is decent at four hours (with a further 12 hours charge provided
through the case) and the splash resistance is handy for those who might want
to run with these.

However, all of that is eclipsed by one uber-annoying thing: the damn buttons.
Like Beats, you have a physical button to press which allows you to
play/pause, skip, activate your voice assistant or adjust the volume. So far,
no problem. The amount of force necessary to get any of these features to
activate means you’re basically smacking the buds into your ear canal in a
manner which I found to be actively painful.

That alone makes the Urbanista Tokyo a (literal) pain to use, and hard to
recommend. Look elsewhere.

_[Buy
now](http://www.awin1.com/cread.php?awinmid=6625&awinaffid=73846&clickref=customid&p=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.clasohlson.com%2Fuk%2FUrbanista-
Tokyo-Wireless-Earphones%2F38-8704-1)_

### **13\. Hooke Verse**

[£190.12, Amazon](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Hooke-Audio-HV014WH-Condenser-
Microphone/dp/B076P7DLQN?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)

![Hooke Verse binaural microphone](/content/dam/recommended/2019/03/25/Hooke-
Verse_trans_NvBQzQNjv4BqgsaO8O78rhmZrDxTlQBjdO0Jyi0jPPD6Zx1hiwTPhlc.jpg?imwidth=480)

This one is a bit of a cuckoo in the nest really. It’s a binaural microphone
that’s been cunningly disguised as a set of headphones. Basically, that means
you plug it into your ears and it is capable of recording sound exactly as you
hear it. For a journalist, it’s ideal for interviewing people, but I can also
imagine it’d be a cool piece of gear for an aspiring filmmaker, or those who
want to create really immersive holiday videos.

If this was a review of microphones it’d be near the top, but as a set of
wireless headphones they are only really capable of going loud, without any
refinement. There are better options, if you’re not bothered by the microphone
quality.

_[Buy now](https://www.amazon.co.uk/Hooke-Audio-HV014WH-Condenser-
Microphone/dp/B076P7DLQN?tag=telegraphaffiliate-21&ascsubtag=customid-21)_

##### **Frequently asked questions about wireless headphones:**

### **How do wireless headphones work?**

The answer is Bluetooth, but how it works is hugely complicated and boring, so
allow me to explain as simply as I can.

Imagine two people standing on either side of a river waving at each other –
that’s your headphones and your music player. Music Player has some heavy
boxes that won’t float across the river. So it breaks them down into teeny
tiny units that do float. When they get to the other side, Headphones rebuilds
them exactly as they were. That’s basically what’s happening with Bluetooth
except it’s basically instantaneous. And it uses radio waves rather than a
river, which leads us nicely onto the next question...

### **Are Bluetooth headphones safe?**

You’ve probably heard the (unproven) claims that holding a phone next to your
head is bad for your, because the radio waves go through your head and cause
cancer, right? Bluetooth also uses radio waves, so is it open to the same
accusations?

Well, even if those claims had been consistently proven, which they haven’t,
it’s still quite different. A mobile phone transmitter and receiver is much
more powerful, designed to project signals over a huge distance. Bluetooth is
designed to transmit and receive from a distance of 10 metres or less. The
signal is so weak that it’s not even comparable. So don’t worry about it.

### **Do Bluetooth headphones lose quality?**

Well… kind of. Don’t get me wrong, you can get some very good quality wireless
headphones. Generally the amount of information you can transmit over
Bluetooth is smaller than you’d get with a wired headphone. To circumvent
this, Bluetooth transmitters in your music player strip out some of the audio
quality at frequencies you usually can’t hear to make the file smaller.
Usually you can’t really tell, but the cumulative effect of stripping out
these unnecessary parts of the music file does gradually become noticeable
after a while.

That being said, as I mentioned before, I don’t have an audiophile’s ear, so I
didn’t really notice the difference. If you’re big on hearing every detail of
your music, go with a wire, but unless you’re a real music nerd, don’t worry
about it, you won’t be able to tell.
